newsitem.title: INDIA: India soybean trade unhappy on new import rules.
newsitem.headline: India soybean trade unhappy on new import rules.

text.p: Indian soybean exporters on Tuesday expressed concern over the government's ban on free oilseeds imports in its new trade policy.
The government in its Export-Import (Exim) Policy for 1997-2002, announced on Monday, allowed only state agencies to import oilseeds.

"The import of soybean and other oilseeds which have been canalised (regulated) through state trading agencies will not be of much help to the processors," said Satyanarayan Saboo, a leading oilmeal trader.
Industry officials said allowing free import of oilseeds by private importers would have helped use of idle crushing capacity, currently about 60 percent.
Traders said soybean arrivals were around 1,500 tonnes per day compared with 15,000 tonnes in the central Indian markets, the hub of India's soybean industry.
They said soybean was quoted at 12,500-12,700 rupees per tonne compared with 10,300-10,500 same time last year.
Soymeal for export was quoted at $310 per tonne FAS which was around $221 same time a year ago, traders said.
